conclusion: The problem involves determining the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity of a basketball during its collision with the ground, considering air resistance and energy conservation.
The potential energy at height H is converted into kinetic energy just before the first collision, giving KE_initial = (1/2)mv_0^2 = mgH.
The potential energy at height h after the first collision is converted into kinetic energy, giving KE_final = (1/2)mv_1^2 = mgh.
The force of air resistance is given as F_air = -λmg, and the work done by air resistance during descent is W_descent = -λmgH.
The work done by air resistance during ascent is W_ascent = -λmgh.
The total work done by air resistance is W_total = W_descent + W_ascent = -λmg(H + h).
By the work-energy theorem, the change in kinetic energy is ΔKE = (1/2)mv_1^2 - (1/2)mv_0^2.
The total work done by forces is W_total = mg(H - h) - λmg(H + h), leading to W_total = mg((1 - λ)H - (1 + λ)h).
Equating the total work done to the change in kinetic energy gives (1/2)mv_1^2 - (1/2)mv_0^2 = -mg((1 - λ)H - (1 + λ)h).
Substituting KE_initial = mgH and KE_final = mgh into the equation gives mgh - mgH = -mg((1 - λ)H - (1 + λ)h).
Dividing both sides by mg gives h - H = -((1 - λ)H - (1 + λ)h).
Simplifying the equation gives h - H = -H(1 - λ) + h(1 + λ).
